awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social Inequalities and Respiratory Mortality in Newfoundland during the 1918 Influenza Pandemic
awd_abstract_narration:
The 1918 influenza pandemic has been studied from the perspectives of epidemiologists, historians, virologists, and social scientists, providing increasingly more insight on how biology and culture interact to result in unequal mortality outcomes. This doctoral dissertation project will investigate population health and social inequalities that contributed to the 1918 pandemic outcomes, taking into account both influenza and other respiratory illnesses that were circulating during the pandemic. Advancing knowledge about how past behaviors and population structure affected previous pandemic outcomes can contribute to contemporary knowledge of human behaviors, population structure, and potential infectious threats. This project will also support science outreach and education activities at the research location and home institution.

The investigators will analyze the impact of population heterogeneity, specifically in terms of social inequalities, on mortality associated with four respiratory diseases (influenza, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and bronchitis) during the 1918 influenza pandemic on the island of Newfoundland. Newfoundland represents a unique opportunity for the use of historical archival data to reconstruct the political economy, population, and social structure of a pre-industrial society in a way that is directly comparable to its Western neighbors. Early 20th century Newfoundland's urban and rural regions varied greatly in their demographic and socioeconomic characteristics; therefore, research questions will address how age, sex, gendered divisions of labor, crowding, income, and education facilitate social inequality that leads to differential disease mortality. The data used will be collected from the Provincial Archives of Newfoundland & Labrador, and will include yearly vital statistics, death records, newspapers, diaries, photograph collections, and literature. Survival analysis and seasonal regression models will be used to quantify differential mortality across the island, but qualitative data are also critical to understanding the cultural norms of men, women, and children during the early 20th century, and an anthropological perspective on 1918 pandemic mortality. This project is jointly supported by the NSF's Biological Anthropology and Cultural Anthropology programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this dissertation research were to investigate the inequalities and outcomes of the 1918 influenza pandemic on the island of Newfoundland. Newfoundland has extensive and detailed historical records through which we can study this major historical pandemic and learn about the drivers of different pandemic outcomes within a heterogeneous population. Quantitative data in the form of death records, vital statistics, and censuses, as well as qualitative data in the form of official government reports, newspapers, and intragovernmental correspondence, were collected from The Rooms Provincial Archives in St. John’s, Newfoundland & Labrador between 2019 and 2022. Because pandemic pathogens interact with other infectious diseases in important ways, our research focused on pandemic influenza, pneumonia, tuberculosis, bronchitis, whooping cough, and measles. Two of the primary objectives of this research were to (1) analyze post-pandemic patterns of tuberculosis mortality in Newfoundland to see how the pandemic may have influenced epidemiology of one of the primary health burdens in the early 20th century, and (2) contextualize pandemic outcomes from pandemic influenza, pneumonia, tuberculosis, bronchitis, measles, and whooping cough to explore whether mortality and survivorship from these diseases in Newfoundland were typical, amplified, or unique compared to those of non-pandemic periods.

 

The primary outcome of the first objective was that there were no significant changes in tuberculosis mortality that can be directly attributed to the 1918 influenza pandemic in Newfoundland. This is a distinctly different observation than what has been observed for the United States, where tuberculosis mortality fell rapidly after the 1918 influenza pandemic, likely due to selective effects against people who had both tuberculosis and pandemic flu. This is an important finding because there is no generalizable selective mortality pattern for distinct populations, especially those as different as the United States and Newfoundland in the early 20th century. The primary outcome of the second objective was that there were no significant differences in survivorship among the four regions of Newfoundland during the pandemic, while there were significant differences in non-pandemic periods among the four regions. The primary conclusion from this research is that pandemic outcomes need to be compared to experiences with infectious diseases in typical, non-pandemic years (e.g., 1918 influenza versus seasonal influenza) to understand if pandemic inequalities are typical, magnified, or unique compared to what could be expected.

 

The products of this dissertation contribute to knowledge and theory of biological and biocultural anthropology to encourage its more purposeful integration with demography and long-term changes in health that are driven, in part, by humans’ relationship with infectious diseases. Biocultural anthropologists can gain a better understanding of ultimate causes of disease and mortality through this lens, specifically the behaviors, interactions, and social structures that contribute to overall health outcomes. This is a broad contribution, but it can be more specifically applied to pandemic contexts, as well. In the case of Newfoundland more specifically, the island only had one relatively small developing urban center at the time but was otherwise overwhelmingly rural. It is uncommon for such detailed historical data to exist for such a population, but the availability of data to investigate differential pandemic outcomes between rural and urbanizing spaces on the island make it directly comparable to the experiences of other nominally Western populations like the United States, Canada, and other North Atlantic nations.

 

There were several major categories of products of this dissertation and award: academic products, K-12 education products, and undergraduate research experience. This dissertation produced three peer-reviewed journal articles primarily authored by Co-PI van Doren, all three of which were published in leading biological anthropology journals. Over the life of the award, the Co-PI also presented five talks at professional conferences. This dissertation research has also been compiled into a pamphlet, worksheet, and animation by Futurum Careers for dissemination to secondary schools. Futurum Careers is a free online resource and magazine aimed at encouraging 14-19-year-olds worldwide to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medicine (STEM), and social sciences, humanities, and the arts for people and the economy (SHAPE). These resources allow young students to be exposed to anthropology and to understand what it means to do research as an anthropologist. Finally, the award allowed the Co-PI to hire three undergraduate research assistants for one year to learn how to read, catalogue, and analyze qualitative archival data. For all three of these undergraduates, this was their first professional research experience.
